text: I contacted a good friend that works in the industry for setting up led panels for installations last night, he said he would be happy to take a call about the feasibility and technical requirements for setting up a rig like we are looking at here. Said signing an nda and all that would not be an issue.  He works for this company <http://www.kentav.com/>
<@U02F8LF2X>: <@U02E3CRMA> can you guys take a look into that company and let me know if we should set up a call?
I think the issue is the pixel pitch of LED panels compared to lcd panels
let me get some numbers...
<http://www.unilumin.com/cont/UTV0.8_225_1267.html>
<@U0EL0GLEL>: nice!
ok there's an example with super small pixel pitch
and it works out to something like 545x545 for a 26.7" diagonal
if my math is right
so I think given that viewing distance is going to be super duper short, we want lcds
make sense?
Do we get weird angle of approach issues with LCD?
I can check to see what the planar ones say for viewing angle
noticed this for planars: " Power supplies are off-board and can be rack-mounted at a distance from the tiles"
something to consider when thinking about heat
here we go <@U026PHQ3J>: 178 degree viewing angle
question from the peanut gallery: does moving the power supply to rack-mounted also make for a slimmer/lighter panel wrt the cubby door?
probably
it at least doesnâ€™t eat up cubby space

"Planar Mosaic power supplies are not built into the video tiles - they are in rack-mount (1U) modules up to 200 feet (60 meters)
away from the Planar Mosaic video wall"
"A single power supply module can support up to 15 Salvador tiles"
"A single power supply module can support up to 15 Salvador Dalis"
we'd have problems stacking Salvador Dalis 7 high
per unit cost would be higher too
